sen.j: 水馬（すいば）は、ウマに乗って水を渡る、江戸時代、江戸幕府の年中行事のひとつ。
sen.e: Suiba was an annual event in the Edo period held by Edo bakufu (a Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in which people rode horses across water.

sen.j: 6、7月ころ、書院番、御小姓番、大番、ならびに鶴見、曲木、諏訪部、浦部4箇所の厩付の諸士および田安、一橋、清水の三卿付の諸士らが、数名ないし十数名出動し、隅田川すじでおこなわれた。
sen.e: Suiba was held around June or July at the Sumida-gawa river, with the participants being samurai numbering from several up to several dozen who were either in the position of shoinban (castle guard), okoshoban (official guard in the Tokugawa Shogunate) or oban (a group of guards in the Edo shogunate), or working at one of four stables (in Tsurumi, Magaki, Suwabe or Urabe), or working for one of the three families related to the shogun (the Tayasu, the Hitotsubashi or the Shimizu).

Several, or several dozen of, samurais participated in Suiba, who were shoinban (castle guard), okoshoban (official guard in the Tokugawa Shogunate), oban (a group of guards in the Edo shogunate), samurais working at one of four stables (in Tsurumi, Magaki, Suwabe or Urabe), and samurais working for one of the three families related to the shogun (the Tayasu, the Hitotsubashi or the Shimizu), and it was held around June or July at the Sumida-gawa river,.

sen.e: Suiba was held around June or July at the Sumida-gawa river with the participation of several dozens of samurai; namely, the shoinban (castle guard), the okoshoban (official guard in the Tokugawa Shogunate), the oban (a group of guards in the Edo shogunate), samurai working at one of four stables (in Tsurumi, Magaki, Suwabe or Urabe), and samurai working for one of the three families related to the shogun (the Tayasu, the Hitotsubashi or the Shimizu).

sen.j: 騎者は晒麻布を太白糸で縫ってつくった白、紺、浅黄などの、家紋を染め出した水半纏を着用した。
sen.e: The horse riders wore a white, dark blue or light yellow mizu-hanten (a kind of short coat for a in-water use: mizu means water) made from weathered hemp cloth which was sewn with taihaku ito (a thick white silk thread) and had a family crest dyed on it.

sen.j: ウマには麻の水腹帯をかたく締めた。
sen.e: Their horses were wrapped tightly with a hemp cloth around the abdominal area.

sen.j: まずウマの平首（ひらくび）の右方に沿って水中にひきいれる。
sen.e: First, the horse was led to the water by its rider holding the right side of its neck.

sen.j: その足のたたないところにくると臀後にしりぞき、腹帯の輪にとりそえた手綱を操ってうちわたした。
sen.e: When the water got too deep for the horse's legs to touch the bottom, the rider went behind the horse and drove it forward using the reins, which were attached to rings on the hemp cloth.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When the water got too deep for the horse to touch the bottom of the river, the rider moved behind the horse and drove it forward using the reins attached to rings on the hemp cloth.
sen.cmt: I wonder if native English speakers understand this sentence or not.
sen.e: When the water got too deep for the horse to touch the bottom of the river, the rider moved back until he was sitting on the horse's buttocks and drove the horse forward using reins attached to rings on the hemp cloth.

sen.j: 熟練の騎者は水半纏のうえに短い水袴を着て、ウマにも水鞍と水鎧をつけた。
sen.e: Experienced riders wore a short mizu-bakama (a pair of trousers worn over a kimono in water) and a mizu-hanten, and on their horse they put a mizu-kura (a saddle used in water) and mizu-yoroi (armor used in water).

sen.j: ウマの足のたたないところにくると平首に沿って下り、轡をとりたすけてすすみ、臀後にしりぞいてうちわたした。
sen.e: When the water got too deep for the horse's legs to touch the bottom, the rider dismounted from the horse at its neck, helped it forward using the bit, before moving behind the horse to drive it on.

sen.j: 旧日本軍の騎兵科の教練にも水馬がおこなわれ、水中騎兵練習として重視されていた。
sen.e: Suiba was adopted as a drill by the cavalry department of the Imperial Japanese Army and became an important in-water exercise.
